title: Tourist Website Logos
content:
Good Evening Artists!

I am seeking assistance on a logo redesign for our biggest in-house project: [http://keytosavannah.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20090608105821/http:/keytosavannah.com/)

Key to Savannah is basically a tourism website that brings helpful tools and information to both tourists and locals of Savannah, GA.

Closely behind Key To Savannah, came Key To Tybee. Tybee Island is Savannah’s beach, so we launched [http://keytotybee.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20090608105821/http:/keytotybee.com/).

Our current logo isn’t translating well across all of our media. On our nametags, you can’t even read the words “KEY TO” and everyone asks if we are from Savannah, so it is time for a change.

Here are the logos as they are now.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090608105821im_/http:/typophile.com/files/logo-1_6741.gif)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090608105821im_/http:/typophile.com/files/logo-2_5835.gif)

So my first attempt at redesign turned out visually pleasing, but they didn’t really communicate much relating the mark, or the brand. I removed the key and the sticker and ended up with just a fancy looking title:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090608105821im_/http:/typophile.com/files/logo2-1_4997.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090608105821im_/http:/typophile.com/files/logo2-2_3971.jpg)

So, back to the drawing board I went, and following the advice of some fellow artists, I started with the key, and THEN to the typography, so here is where I’m at:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090608105821im_/http:/typophile.com/files/keytosavannah-logo_4551.gif)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090608105821im_/http:/typophile.com/files/keytotybee-logo_5561.gif)

Currently, I am working on some kerning and proportions with these, but I wanted to get them up so I could benefit from as much feedback as possible. Please let me know if you like them, and what would make them better. We plan on releasing many “key to” sites in the future so this one has got to stick. This is my last chance to change it this one time. I feel that the site’s popularity is about to take hold, so the time is now!!

Thank you SO much!  
All the best,  
awesome.omen
author: awesome.omen

comments.content:
the new logos are pretty complex and have an air of being older than the originals (not necessarily a good thing)

my suggestion is to steer away from the literal key reference - or at the very least have EITHER the word or the icon not both, nor combined into one mark.

perhaps the skylines from the cities could make up the key teeth, or maybe the key mark is a generic (and simple) icon that will work well across most/any collateral.

I really reckon the whole key thing is naff. Maybe take a different spin on a key ... think maps, think map keys/legends, simplification of directions etc.

ideas anyway.

—————  
**Paul Ducco**  
 [Graphic Designer](http://web.archive.org/web/20090608105821/http:/www.solid-creative.com/) - Melbourne

Too complex? Would color help them to look more modern?

It’s funny you mention using the skyline as the teeth of the key, that’s how I arrived at these. The skyline was too much so the city name took the place of the skyline.

Maybe they are just too dark and need something to pull it all together, I’m working on some new ones. Thank you Paul for your feedback and great advice!

Any comments would be SO appreciated, thanks all!

I think the concept could probably work but I’m not digging either of the fonts you’ve used. That K is really overpowering the basic shape and the art-deco fonts make these look like they’re for retirement communities or something.
The typefaces do not go together. They’re far too decorative to be used together. The more simple the better in this case I think.

Thank you everyone for your feedback. I went back to the drawing board, and would like to submit another idea for critique.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090608105821im_/http:/typophile.com/files/keyto-logo_4724.jpg)

I placed it on our [development site](http://web.archive.org/web/20090608105821/http:/keytosavannah.dev.emarketsouth.com/) so you could see it in context. Please let me know what you think and if you think I’ve made progress. I’m quite fond of this one so far. I would appreciate any feedback you could offer.

It’s not working.

When the first iteration isn’t working forget about visual effects and colours all together, because they just tend to distract you from the actual development process. You used three different fonts in just one logo. Needless to say they don’t complement each other.

I would concentrate on something simple. What is Savannah like? Try to incorporate that in your logo. Don’t use too many fonts. And don’t use colours at the beginning.  
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_  
_Robert Koritnik_
The original logo isn’t that bad...maybe you can just enhance it instead of reworking it from scratch.

But the logo isn’t always going to be for Savannah. The important part is the KEY TO.

This has to work for [Key To Tybee](http://web.archive.org/web/20090608105821/http:/keytotybee.com/) as well, and any other Key To site we develop. So I can’t start with “what Savannah is like.” Right?

I keep hearing, start with something simple... is it just the fonts that are bad, or the whole entire concept?

I have to brand the KEY TO. Savannah is second to the KEY TO.

Any suggestions on where to go from here?
The original logo isn’t working for us now. It doesn’t translate well across media. I can’t help but feel it needs to change.

I’m going to go against the flow and state that the first round of revisions were quite good. The ’key’ element is there, but not overpowering. It’s a nice ’aha’ if you see it but doesn’t get in the way.

Yes, it’s a retro feel. I like that. It gives it some personality. Does it fit with the business needs? I don’t know. But if the places the web site is focusing on are somewhat historic “good old mainstreet” type venues, I think it’s quite appropriate.
I agree with aluminum. I like the retro feel. Maybe place with a few more fonts and sizing. I dig it man. I’d go more in this direction. good job.

Well in your logo, “Key to” doesn’t look like the primary part. Check logos, that have primary part and dynamic secondary part. So. I suggest you first design your “Key to” part, then you’ll work on incorporating other parts.

By simple I mean, no colours, one or MAYBE two fonts at most (in the whole logo, not in “Key to”), no visual effects etc. KISS principle.

Your logos so far were “Savannah”. KeyTo was just something that was added to it.

And when you’ll concentrate on the KeyTo part, don’t think of it as a key. Think of what the key represents? What it does. Get associations, that will lead you to some great clever solution. And think of the purpose of these kites/services...  
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_  
_Robert Koritnik_
